Dear Yulonda Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications
Description Rule 112. (1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall
not permit a child caring institution staff member to begin working
unless all of the following has been completed using the forms,
and in the manner, prescribed by the department:
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member was reported to carry a bottle around on shift that
contained alcohol. On one occasion the staff was sent for drug
and alcohol testing and there was alcohol detected in their
system. The staff was not terminated following this and continued
to be allowed to work with youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on March 3, 2025.
Complainant said she did not have any additional information to
provide.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on March
10, 2025. Youth A said she was placed at Freedom Center and
Staff 1 worked with her on several occasions. Youth A said Staff 1
was “creepy” and would “linger” around the youth, however denied
ever physically touching her. Youth A said Staff 1 had alcohol in a
Gatorade bottle at work, stating she opened it and smelled it.
Youth A was not able to remember the date, time, or location of
when this occurred. Youth A said Staff 1 puked while working and
passed out in the staff breakroom, stating she “heard about it” but
refused to say from who.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on March
10, 2025. Youth B said she was placed at Freedom Center and
Staff 1 worked with her on several occasions. Youth B said Staff 1
“always came to work drunk” and “smelled like booze” whenever
he was working. Youth B said Staff 1 had a “creep vibe” but never
did anything to her. Youth B said Staff 1 passed out in the
2

breakroom one time and she opened his water bottle, and it
smelled like alcohol. Youth B was not able to give a day or time
this occurred. Youth B said Staff 1 was “always stumbling around
and slurring his words”, stating “all” the staff were aware of it.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on March
10, 2025. Youth C said she was placed at Freedom Center and
Staff 1 worked with her on several occasions. Youth C said Staff 1
was “quiet” and mainly sat and observed the youth. Youth C said
she never smelled alcohol on him however noted he did wear
“strong cologne”. Youth C said she never had any concerns about
him being under the influence of alcohol. Youth C said she never
felt any safety concerns around him. Youth C said he would
encourage her to work her program, and she felt he was “a good
staff”.
Staff 1 was called on March 12, 2025, March 17, 2025, and
March 19, 2025. Staff 1 did not answer or return the phone calls.
Staff 1 is no longer employed at Vista Maria and therefore was not
interviewed.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on March 12, 2025. Staff
2 said she worked with Staff 1 regularly. Staff 2 said she never
smelled alcohol on Staff 1. Staff 2 said she always thought Staff 1
was a little “off” further describing him as slow to act on directions
he was given like he was “stuck” in one place for a while before
doing what was asked of him. Staff 2 said she never saw him
throwing up or passed out in the break room. Staff 2 said she
never smelled his Gatorade or water bottle. Staff 2 said she did
not have concerns about Staff 1 and thought he was just learning
the job and it was taking him a bit longer than some to pick up on
things he needed to do.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on March 12, 2025. Staff
3 said she worked at Freedom Center with Staff 1. Staff 3 said she
worked with Staff 1 on January 8, 2025, when both of them were
injured by Youth D. Staff 3 said Staff 1 did not appear under the
influence of drugs or alcohol on January 8, 2025, or any other shift
she worked with him. Staff 3 said she never smelled alcohol on
Staff 1 or noticed any concerning behaviors. Staff 3 said Staff 1
was a quiet staff who did not engage a lot with the youth.
Supervisor Z was interviewed via telephone March 12, 2025.
Supervisor Z said she did not work the floor with Staff 1, however
was his supervisor and would interact with him “in passing”.
Supervisor Z said on January 8, 2025, Staff 1 came to her due to
3

being injured by Youth D. Supervisor Z said she could smell
alcohol on Staff 1, and he was slurring his words and “walking
funny”. Supervisor Z said she contacted Supervisor Y who
contacted Human Resource Representative and Staff 1 was sent
to Concentra for an exam and drug test. Supervisor Z said Staff 1
was positive for alcohol twice, the first test being a 0.034 level and
second test being 0.042 level. Supervisor Z said this was the first
time she had any indication that Staff 1 was under the influence.
Supervisor Z denied any staff or youth ever reporting concerns
regarding Staff 1 to her previously. Supervisor Z said she never
saw Staff 1 puking or passed out and no other staff or youth
reported this information to her either. Supervisor Z said Staff 1’s
employment was terminated the next day.
Program Manager was interviewed via telephone on March
19, 2025. Program Manager said he supervised the Freedom
Center program and through that role had interacted with Staff 1.
Program Manager said the interactions he had with Staff 1 was
normally in passing and he did not work the floor with Staff 1.
Program Manager said he saw Staff 1 briefly on January 8, 2025,
and did not notice any smell of alcohol or concerns with his
behaviors during that interaction. Program Manager said Staff 1
was injured by Youth D and met with Supervisor Z. Program
Manager said Supervisor Z contacted him due to concerns with
Staff 1’s behaviors and smell of alcohol on his breath. Program
Manager said Human Resource Representative was called and
informed of the concern and added a drug test to the exam for
Staff 1. Program Manager said Staff 1 did not have his own
transportation so a Lyft ride had been arranged for Staff 1 to and
from Concentra. Program Manager said it had been planned for
Staff 1 to go home after the exam due to the injury. Program
Manager said he was then informed Staff 1 had tested positive for
alcohol on two different tests and he was terminated the following
morning. Program Manager said he never had any concerns
about Staff 1 drinking on the job or being under the influence at
work. Program Manager said no staff or youth ever reported any
concerns about Staff 1’s behaviors or concerns of him being under
the influence while at work to him.
Human Resource Representative was interviewed via
telephone on March 19, 2025. Human Resource Representative
said she was notified on January 8, 2025, by Supervisor Z that
Staff 1 was injured on the job and when she met with him, he
smelled like alcohol and was showing visible signs of intoxication
so requested he was drug tested. Human Resource
Representative said she called Concentra and requested they do
4

a blood alcohol test for Staff 1 while he was there for an exam due
to the workplace injury. Human Resource Representative said the
plan for Staff 1 had been to go home after the exam at Concentra.
Human Resource Representative said she received the alcohol
results the following day and Staff 1 was terminated immediately.
Human Resource Representative said she never worked directly
with Staff 1 and never had any concerns brought to her prior to
this incident. Human Resource Representative said in her position
she would be brought into any employee concerns or disciplinary
actions and Staff 1 never had anything brought up during his
employment.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
other than Staff 1’s Termination Letter. The Termination
Letter dated January 9, 2025, was reviewed and noted that
on January 8, 2025, Staff 1 went to Concentra due to a
work-related injury and was tested for alcohol which
produced two positive test results. In addition, it noted “co-
workers and leaders reported not only your actions, but a
noticeable odor of alcohol in your presence.” Staff 1
participated in onboarding training which reviewed all
policies and procedures between November 13, 2024, and
November 19, 2024.
• Vista Maria policy for Drug/Alcohol-Free Workplace was
reviewed. The policy specifically states, “Employees are
prohibited from the use, sale, dispensing, distribution,
possession, or manufacture of illegal drugs, controlled
substances, narcotics, or alcoholic beverages or other
substances that might affect employee performance on
Vista Maria’s work sites.” In addition, it outlines that
employees are subject to disciplinary action, up to and
including termination, for violations of the policy including
“being under the influence of controlled or other substances
affecting performance while working or using such
substances while working”.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as Staff 1 tested positive
twice after being injured at work, showing he was under the
influence of alcohol while working which is against the agency
policy. The agency responded appropriately and terminated his
employment after becoming aware of his positive alcohol test.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: A staff member at Vista Maria tested positive for alcohol on duty after a workplace injury, confirming allegations of being under the influence. The facility promptly terminated the employee upon receiving the test results. While the report states the agency responded appropriately after the incident, it also notes the situation occurred because existing policies were not proactively enforced to prevent such conduct.
